awd_titl_txt: Analytic Number Theory over Function Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
Number theory is an area of mathematics that centers on the ordinary counting numbers and their behavior when we add and multiply them. While problems in this area are often simple to state, they can be fiendishly difficult to solve. The subfield of function field number theory aims to obtain insight on these problems by considering a kind of model or parallel universe where numbers behave differently. We consider what happens when we add or multiply numbers as normal but, except, instead of carrying digits, we simply drop the excess. Certainly arithmetic is a little easier with this modified rule, but more surprisingly, some of the most important problems in number theory become easier as well, with even some of the most difficult ones becoming solvable. (Technically, we should work in binary, or any prime base, rather than our usual base 10, for this.) Alternately, we can describe this variant arithmetic as the addition or multiplication of polynomial functions in a single variable. In this setting, we can connect number-theoretic questions to geometry, by viewing the graph of the polynomial as a geometric object. In this award  the PI's research uses geometric tools to solve new problems in this area.

The PI's research has resolved function field analogues of classical problems in number theory, including the twin primes conjecture and Chowla's conjecture (both joint with Shusterman), cases of the Ramanujan conjecture (joint with Templier), and conjectures about moments of L-functions. In this award the PI will continue along these lines, proving additional results about the distribution of prime numbers, L-function moments, and automorphic forms, and work in further directions such as non-abelian Cohen-Lenstra heuristics. These works are all based on etale cohomology theory, where the foundational result, Deligne's Riemann Hypothesis, allows many different analytic problems (problems about proving some inequality) to be reduced to cohomology problems (problems about calculating some of the cohomology groups of a variety or sheaf). The relevant varieties are high-dimensional, and calculating the necessary cohomology groups requires techniques like vanishing cycles theory and the characteristic cycle.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI undertook a project with Melanie Matchett Wood on the moment method for random algebraic structures. To apply the moment method to the understand the distribution of the heights of a population of people, we would first calculate the average height, or mean, and then the average of the square of the difference between each person's height and the average height, or variance. We would then consider averages of higher powers of the height. Understanding the average of every power of the height often suffices to understand the distribution. The same approach applies to other populations of real numbers and real random variables. However, mathematicians often consider populations whose members are not just numbers but whole number systems with their own notions of addition and multiplication, or other algebraic strucures. The PI defined moments for these structures and explained when these moments suffice to determine the distribution. Unlike in the classical case, it is often possible to calculate the fraction of the population that has a property of interest directly from the moments. Prior work had studied the moment problem for particular algebraic structures, but never in the level of generality of the PI's work. This work is likely to make research at the intersection of algebra and probability easier in the future. The PI and Wood have already applied their results to class groups, an algebraic structure of interest in number theory. Other mathematicians have applied the same results to Galois groups and p-adic random matrices, and further applications are expected. This work is described in more detail in the article Probability and Number Theory Collide - in a Moment in Quanta Magazine.

The PI also worked on the relation between number theory, exponential sums, and geometry. The PI gave a new construction of multiple Dirichlet series, an important tool in analytic number theory, by a simple geometric idea. In future work, this construction should give new interesting examples of multiple Dirichlet series, applications to arithmetic problems, and connections to other areas of mathematics. The PI proved both upper and lower bounds for Kloosterman sums, an important class of exponential sums. The lower bounds can be used to show that some approaches to approximate quantities of interest in number theory cannot always give a very accurate approximation. In joint work with Márton Erdèlyi and Árpád Tóth, the PI described the geometric structure underlying some estimates they proved for matrix Kloosterman sums. 

The PI also worked in other fields. In combinatorics, the PI made progress on the union closed set conjecture, about overlaps between sets, by suggesting a method to improve on breakthrough work of Gilmer. In topology and algebraic geometry, in joint work with Daniel Litt and Aaron Landesman, the PI showed that when surfaces are deformed in every possible way, curves on surfaces that are wrapped around those surfaces must loop in ways that are as complicated as possible.
